raw_text:
Malaysia lifts Islamic bank limit
 
 Malaysia's central bank is to relax restrictions on foreign ownership to encourage Islamic banking.
 
 Banks in Malaysia will now be able to sell up to 49% of their Islamic banking units, while the limit on other kinds of bank remains at 30%. RHB, Malaysia's third-biggest lender, is already scouting for a foreign partner for its new Islamic banking unit, the firm told Reuters. The moves put Malaysia ahead of a 2007 deadline to open up the sector. The country's deal to join the World Trade Organisation set that year as a deadline for liberalisation of Islamic banking. Also on Tuesday, the central bank released growth figures showing Malaysia's economy expanded 7.1% in 2004. But growth slowed sharply in the fourth quarter to 5.6%, and the central bank said it expected 6% expansion in 2005.
 
 Malaysia changed the law to allow Islamic banking in 1983. It has granted licences to three Middle Eastern groups, which - along with local players - mean there are eight fully-operational Islamic banking groups in the country. Islamic banks offer services which permit modern banking principles while sticking to Islamic law's ban on the payment of interest. Most of the Malays which make up half the country's population are Muslims.
llama3.2:1b: Malaysia's central bank is relaxing restrictions on foreign ownership for Islamic banks, allowing them to sell up to 49% of their units, compared to the current limit of 30%.
This move puts Malaysia ahead of a 2007 deadline to liberalize Islamic banking and comes after growth figures showed the country's economy expanded by 7.1% in 2004.
llama3.2:3b: Malaysia lifts restrictions on foreign ownership for Islamic banks, allowing 49% stake sales, ahead of a 2007 deadline.
The country has eight fully-operational Islamic banking groups and plans to expand.
gemma2:2b: Malaysia is relaxing restrictions on foreign ownership for its Islamic banks, allowing them to sell up to 49% of their units.
This move follows a 2007 deadline set by Malaysia's WTO deal and aims to further develop this sector.
The country has seen growth in the Islamic banking sector with eight fully-operational institutions operating.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Malaysia has lifted restrictions on foreign ownership and increased its ability to operate an Islamic banking sector, allowing for more diverse offerings.
The central bank is currently looking at potential foreign partners for a new Islamic banking unit in Malaysia, as the 2007 deadline to open up the sector approached.
Malaysian growth figures show that the economy expanded by 7.1% in 2004 but slowed in the fourth quarter to 5.6%, with the central bank expecting 6% expansion in 2005.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Malaysia lifts restrictions on foreign ownership of Islamic banks, allowing 49% and expanding from a 30% limit for other types of banks.
RHB is scouting for a partner to launch an Islamic banking unit.
The move comes ahead of a 2007 WTO deadline for liberalizing the sector.
Malaysia's economy grew by 7.1% in 2004, although growth slowed to 5.6% in the fourth quarter and expectations are for another 6% expansion in 2005.
The country began Islamic banking laws in 1983 with three regional groups operating alongside local banks.
qwen2.5:3b: Malaysia's central bank is lifting restrictions allowing foreign ownership in Islamic banks to 49%, from a previous limit of 30%.
This move, effective for new units, follows Malaysia’s deadline set by its WTO membership in 2007 to liberalize the sector.
RHB has already started exploring partnerships with foreign entities for its new Islamic banking unit.
The economy grew 7.1% in 2004 but slowed to 5.6% in Q4 of that year, expecting a 6% growth in 2005.
Malaysia began allowing Islamic banking in 1983 and has granted licenses to eight fully-operational groups, including those from Middle Eastern countries.
Islamic banks provide modern banking services compliant with Islamic law's prohibition on interest payments.

tinyllama:1.1b: Malaysia has relaxed restrictions on foreign ownership for Islamic banks, allowing them to sell up to a maximum of 49% of their units, while the limit on other kinds of bank remains at 30%.

tinydolphin:1.1b: The summary statement is "Malaysia has approved a relaxation in Islamic bank ownership limits, allowing foreign ownership of Islamic banks to increase."
It explains that under the current set of rules, Islamic banks in Malaysia can have foreign ownership ratios of up to 30%, but this was changed by the central bank.
The new rule allows Islamic banks to sell up to 49% of their units to non-Malaysians while keeping the existing 30% limit in place for other types of lenders.
This move is expected to encourage more businesses to embrace Islamic banking practices and attract foreign investment, paving the way for more growth in Malaysia's economy.
